title: 107_s687
content: The Act is titled the "Higher Education Affordability and Fairness Act" and includes a deduction for higher education expenses under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Higher Education Affordability and Fairness Act" includes a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses paid by an individual during the taxable year, with limitations on the amount that can be deducted for the first 2 years of postsecondary education. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to $5,000 for taxpayers whose credit is reduced to zero under section 25A(d)(1). For eligible students who have completed the first 2 years of postsecondary education, the deduction amount is also limited. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to $10,000, except for specific cases where it is reduced to $5,000 or zero. The deduction is allowed for a maximum of 4 taxable years for each eligible student. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to $10,000 for up to 4 taxable years per eligible student. To claim the deduction, taxpayers must provide specific information about the eligible student on their tax return. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is reduced by certain exclusions and limitations. No deduction is allowed for individuals who can be claimed as dependents by another taxpayer. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is limited to expenses connected to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year or the first 3 months of the next taxable year. Adjustments are made for certain scholarships and veterans benefits. The deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is reduced by amounts received for educational purposes, such as scholarships, veterans benefits, or payments for educational expenses. The tax deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is subject to certain conditions, including enrollment at an eligible educational institution exempt from US income taxation. Married individuals must file joint returns to qualify, and nonresident aliens may be eligible under specific circumstances. The Secretary has the authority to establish regulations for implementation. The IRS can establish regulations for implementing the tax deduction for higher education expenses, and adjustments to adjusted gross income must be made without considering this deduction. The tax code is amended in various sections by inserting "222," before "911" in certain places, and adjustments to adjusted gross income are made without considering the tax deduction for higher education expenses. The amendments made by this section apply to higher education expenses paid after December 31, 2001, for education provided in academic periods starting after that date. The amendment increases the AGI limits for the lifetime learning credit by changing the year from 2003 to 2002. The amount of reduction in the credit is determined based on the ratio of the amount taken into account under subsection (a)(1). The amendment adjusts the AGI limits for the lifetime learning credit, with reductions based on income thresholds. The amendment adjusts AGI limits for the lifetime learning credit based on income thresholds. The modified adjusted gross income is calculated by adding any excluded amounts from gross income under specific sections. The amendment adjusts income limits for the Hope and Lifetime Learning credits based on cost-of-living adjustments. The amendment increases income limits for the Lifetime Learning credit based on cost-of-living adjustments, rounding to the nearest $1,000 if necessary. The amendment increases income limits for the Lifetime Learning credit based on cost-of-living adjustments, rounding to the nearest multiple of $1,000. Coordination with other higher education benefits is also addressed, allowing taxpayers to elect not to have certain sections apply. Effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 2001. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct an annual study to analyze the impact of Federal income tax incentives on higher education tuition rates. The results will be reported to Congress annually. The Senate believes the maximum Pell Grant should be increased to $4,700 to cover a significant portion of college expenses.
